intro: Salvia appendiculata, commonly known as the appendiculate sage, is a perennial herb native to South Africa. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring opposite, lance-shaped leaves with a slightly hairy surface. Its flowers are violet to purple, forming dense spikes at the ends of the stems, and bloom during the summer months. Salvia appendiculata is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is adapted to well-drained, sandy soils.
